children.subject: I don't want to discourage you, but I have two friends who got rejected by Cal. They both did well and got 4.0 GPA at the community college, but the mistake they made was taking class at Cal before transfer. One was Architecture major, another was CS major. If I recall correctly, they both got around C grade for the class they took at Cal...

history.content:
Hey, 

Fellow transfer student here at Berkeley. Just finished my first year. Right off the bat, I want to tell you this... don't ever be discouraged by this or anything else in life that comes at you. In fact, taking EE16A + CS61A over the summer is hard for any first year student here at Berkeley. Especially since 61A is so project heavy. So don't let these courses define you. 

I can't necessarily give you tips on the direction you should take in regards to your application. I believe that's either up to you and/or admission officers insight. But I can tell you this: 

About 3 years ago, I graduated HS with terrible grades. Getting straight C's exiting my senior year. 1500/2400 SAT (took it twice). No college acceptances. Only place that would take my hand was community college. During this time, it was was one of the most awkward times with my parents. My parents were not proud, they were not happy. And they did their job in reminding me that constantly. So I completely understand your feelings about telling your parents. But I stayed calm, I was patient, and I learned from my mistakes. I told my parents and myself... I'll make you proud. I will fix this. Just give me two years, I promise. Two years later, I applied to an ivy league school, numerous UC's, and some privates. I got into nearly all of them. 

What I want to say from all of this, is that it doesn't end here. You should not give up on your goals. You should go straight to your CC counselor you trust, lay out your whole situation with complete honesty, and make a 2 year plan right away. Just straight up hustle. You haven't even started CC yet, you have a long way to go. And you can have an amazing 2 year CC record to make up for 2 bad grades here at Berkeley. 

And to end this. Man, your last sentence really hit me deep. Just trust yourself on that. You will turn yourself around. Odds were against me. How in the world would someone like me get into Berkeley or an IVY league?Don't just tell your parents, show them. Give them a timeline and prove it. I believe in you man.

Remember that no matter what your parents say to you, they say it because they love you. The heart doesn't speak in one language.

children.subject: Yeah, forsure. More than happy too. Will do it later tonight!

@Anon who posted the student's answer, if you could elaborate on what kinds of things you did/ didn't do to become a better, confident version of yourself (the colleges you applied to surely saw that in you), that would be really insightful!
Thanks Mudit. You were a great TA this summer, even though I didn't do well in the class you definitely made it enjoyable. Hope I see you again in the future :)

Adding on to Anon's very well written answer, firstly, wait for the grades. I know that the grades for the summer sessions aren't out yet, so wait for that.

Secondly, what you describe as arrogance in your post, is anything but that. In high school, we usually take a lot more classes (simply by the numbers) than we do in a college semester. It isn't arrogance that made you think you'd be fine with your Python experience but instead it was confidence, that just happened to be coming from naiveté. Don't get me wrong though, everyone starts off naive. Some learn, and some don't. We know where you stand -- so don't be so harsh on yourself. Classes here are hard, you realized that and you acted on it, and that's what's more important. 

Thirdly, as Anon has also said, these 8 weeks of classes cannot and will not define the rest of your college career. You came out of high school and dived straight into the deep end of a pool. That's fine, you'll get there, but you just need to start at the shallower end and make your way there. Community college advisors and your drive will get you there. What you tried to do over this summer was push yourself to the maximum, but it ended up being too much. Don't stop pushing yourself. This doesn't mean you dumb down your schedule to near-nothing, you just find the limit that you can push yourself to, and then keep exceeding that limit bit by bit. 

I don't have much to say about how to deal with parents because that is really... to each their own, but Anon's last sentence should hold regardless.

Hi, I'm the OP. Thanks for your response - I will be starting Berkeley City College next week :)

I want to do EECS because I want to be in the intersection of hardware/software, and having EE in the degree name opens up more opportunities on the hardware side while not really compromising for anything on the software side of things. (On the other hand, I'm not too familiar with people who ended up working in hardware with a software oriented background).

Additionally, I structured my high school junior year around knocking out AP exams for the COE H/SS requirement and natural sciences requirements, which will open more opportunities to take classes in EECS and dive deeper into the material. 

It's for these reasons that I'm not willing to apply as an LS student (A minor reason, if I had applied in high school my app would have been competitive for LS but not enough EECS). Nothing against the people who are doing LSCS, I respect their decision and don't doubt they are intelligent, it's just not for me.

OP: There is no difference in terms of EE as far as EECS and LSCS are concerned. Absolutely none. Not even 1%. If you have follow up questions about this, post away, but if there's a choice between LSCS and not Berkeley, I know what I'd take. This is assuming that LSCS admittance is easier than EECS admittance, which it is, speaking strictly statistically.  (CalAnswers).
Mudit, is it ok if I talk to you some more privately over email or Fb or something else?
Yes, please feel free to email me.

Hi, my dear classmate. I currently a transfer student at Cal from Berkeley City College. I took CS 61A this summer and I feel this class it's extremely challenge.=_= I feel the same thing as you do. I believe most students feel the same. Let's forgot about this class. And REMEMBER you still have one year to go. Work hard on your application and show those application to Cal instructors, maybe your TA, hopefully they could help you. Another thing I want to mention is that, you do not have to get into EECS or CS at L&S. You can apply for applied math, stat or any kind of major at L&S. Then declare major to CS at L&S. I know some people take advantage of this system because AM and STAT have higher accept rates. Here is the link to check it: https://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/infocenter/transfers-major Basically, my suggestion is Get into a higher accept rate major in L&S then declare to CS. But remember, Cal's classes are super challenge, I believe 61A and 16A are their basic level. If you think you cannot handle it, maybe some other UCs are good choices.
Thank you Daniel. I'm glad to have had such a wonderful instructor this summer and hope we will see each other in the future again :)

I want to add my voice of support to all the wonderful responses above; but, like Mudit said, first wait for the grades to be released.

I also want to add the following. Regardless of what your grade may be, use this experience to grow and learn. In many instances, new college students and high-school students miscalculate the necessary load that college courses and projects require, and that is certainly not arrogance. This is, as many have adequately explained, because of the density and depth of what is covered in each college course; more material is covered per week than in high-school/AP classes (and even more so in the summer), and the content is also covered in more detail and with higher rigor. So now take your experience from the summer, reflect on it, and make a plan with a set of goals. Seek advice, they are really valuable. Surround yourself with support that starts from yourself, but keep yourself in check without being too hard on yourself.

I guarantee you that there will be plenty of opportunities to prove, both to yourself and to others, that you learned from this experience. Celebrate your ups and learn from your downs; turn every experience into something positive and you'll do great.

I have personally worked with students at Berkeley who started with a similar story like yours (perhaps different courses) and ended up back at Berkeley after community college. My philosophy is this, if you show at a later time that you have filled the gaps, your old scores should be discounted. I am not saying that this is or isn't how the admission decision process is conducted, because I simply don't know. But for what it's worth, for me as someone who once taught you a course, this will make me proud to have had you as a student.

Never cease to learn and improve; fiat lux!
Thank you Joyce for being such a great TA this summer. Hope to see you in the future :)

Hey. If you're who I think you are, I wanted to say that Berkeley will welcome you back with open arms, if you choose to come back and try those classes again. I myself failed 61C the first time and I had to retake it. The different between you and I, though, was that you actually showed up to the final exam. I didn't. I'm rooting for you!

history.content:
Hi all. I'm going to be a first year community college student this fall, and this summer I took EE16A, CS61A. I bombed these classes (both grades lower than C+, probably failed one in the D range).

Now I'm a bit unsure what to do - I was planning to apply to CoE-EECS a year from now (since I wanted to do a hybrid hardware/software degree), but it already looks like these grades will ensure my application in the trash bin.

I know I could have performed much better in both classes if I managed my time better - I was arrogant, thought my 2 years of Python knowledge + projects in machine learning, deep learning, and computer vision (even took MIT's edX Intro to CS (6.00x) and Circuits (6.002x) class before this) surely meant I could handle both and focus on doing controls projects (kalman filtering, motion planning stuff) during the summer and not spend much time studying.

Boy, was I terribly wrong. Those midterms were very difficult, and even though I dropped my side projects after the first midterm, it was all catch up from that point and 4 weeks is really no time to catch up and keep pace with what's supposed to a semester of material. Especially week 6 onward - I couldn't even do my homeworks because I had so many knowledge gaps that I didn't know where to start, and I basically glued together pieces of 61A homework solutions, 61A Scheme documentation and documented StackOverflow/Github code to put my 61A Scheme project together.

I definitely have developed a new appreciation and respect for Berkeley students and instructors that I never really had in high school; you guys are absolutely amazing for being able to handle and do what you guys do.

I guess at this point, I'm asking what I should do. I am still interested in this field and know this is probably where I want to direct my future, but this summer is a huge blow to whatever chances I may have once had at making it into a good ee/ce school anywhere, forget Berkeley. The worst part will have to be explaining to my parents who bent heaven and earth to get me my education to trust that I can turn this around...
history.subject: [Not a UCB student] Should I even apply to EECS? Bombed 2 classes this summer

history.content:
Hi all. I'm going to be a first year community college student this fall, and this summer I took EE16A, CS61A. I bombed these classes (both grades lower than C+, probably failed one in the D range).

Now I'm a bit unsure what to do - I was planning to apply to CoE-EECS a year from now (since I wanted to do a hybrid hardware/software degree), but it already looks like these grades will ensure my application in the trash bin.

I know I could have performed much better in both classes if I managed my time better - I was arrogant, thought my 2 years of Python knowledge + projects in machine learning, deep learning, and computer vision (even took MIT's edX Intro to CS (6.00x) and Circuits (6.002x) class before this) surely meant I could handle both and focus on doing controls projects (kalman filtering, motion planning stuff) during the summer and not spend much time studying.

Boy, was I terribly wrong. Those midterms were very difficult, and even though I dropped my side projects after the first midterm, it was all catch up from that point and 4 weeks is really no time to catch up and keep pace with what's supposed to a semester of material. Especially week 6 onward - I couldn't even do my homeworks because I had so many knowledge gaps that I didn't know where to start, and I basically glued together pieces of 61A homework solutions, 61A Scheme documentation and documented StackOverflow/Github code to put my 61A Scheme project together.

I thought learning a year's worth of AP content 1 day before the exam was hard. AP exams absolutely pale in comparison to the classes I just took. I definitely have developed a new appreciation and respect for Berkeley students and instructors that I never really had in high school; you guys are absolutely amazing for being able to handle and do what you guys do.

I guess at this point, I'm asking what I should do. I am still interested in this field and know this is probably where I want to direct my future, but this summer is a huge blow to whatever chances I may have once had at making it into a good ee/ce school anywhere, forget Berkeley. The worst part will have to be explaining to my parents who bent heaven and earth to get me my education to trust that I can turn this around...

Hi all. I'm going to be a first year community college student this fall, and this summer I took EE16A, CS61A. I bombed these classes (both grades lower than C+, probably failed one in the D range).

Now I'm a bit unsure what to do - I was planning to apply to CoE-EECS a year from now (since I wanted to do a hybrid hardware/software degree), but it already looks like these grades will ensure my application in the trash bin.

I know I could have performed much better in both classes if I managed my time better - I was arrogant, thought my 2 years of Python knowledge + projects in machine learning, deep learning, and computer vision (even took MIT's edX Intro to CS (6.00x) and Circuits (6.002x) class before this) surely meant I could handle both while doing side projects in controls during the summer and not spend as much time studying.

Boy, was I terribly wrong. Those midterms were very difficult, and even though I dropped my side projects after the first midterm, it was all catch up from that point and 4 weeks is really no time to catch up on what's supposed to be half a semester of material.

I thought learning a year's worth of AP content 1 day before the exam was hard. AP exams absolutely pale in comparison to the classes I just took.

I definitely have developed a new appreciation and respect for Berkeley students and instructors that I never really had in high school; you guys are absolutely amazing for being able to handle and do what you guys do.

I guess at this point, I'm asking what I should do. I am still interested in this field and know this is probably where I want to direct my future, but this summer is a huge blow to whatever chances I may have once had at making it into a good ee/ce/cs school anywhere, forget Berkeley. The worst part will have to be explaining to my parents who bent heaven and earth to get me my education to trust that I can turn this around...
